choices.text: Injection Carboprost
Injection Oxytocin
Injection Tranexamic Acid
Injection Methergine

questions.text: A 24y primigravida is in labor in the 2nd stage. The resident asks the nurse to keep everything ready for active management of the 3rd stage of labor. What drug should the nurse have ready?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Injection Oxytocin

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor:

  • Described by the WHO in 2007
  • Involves mainly 3 basic steps.
    • Administering a uterotonic
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Uterine massage
  • AMTSL prevents atonic PPH.
  • In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
    • Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.
    • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed)
  • In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (!00 mcg IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women))
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
  • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH

 

 

Ref: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/277276/9789241550420-eng.pdf

choices.text: Misoprostol 600 mcg PO
Inj Carboprost IM
Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV
Inj Methylergometrine 200 mcg IV

questions.text: A 34y G2 who was induced for severe preeclampsia at 34 weeks has just delivered. Which is the uterotonic drug of choice in the 3rd stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

  • Described by the WHO in 2007
  • Involves mainly 3 basic steps.
    • Administering a uterotonic
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Uterine massage
  • AMTSL prevents atonic PPH.
  • In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
    • Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.
    • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed)
  • In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (!00 mcg IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women))
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
  • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH
  • In this patient, methylergometrine will NOT be given as preeclampsia is a contra-indication

choices.text: Misoprostol
Carboprost
Syntometrine
Methylergometrine

questions.text: A 35y asthmatic was induced for FGR at 37 weeks. She is now in the 3rd stage of labor having delivered a 2 kg female baby. Following delivery of the placenta, she starts bleeding profusely. The uterus is atonic. Which uterotone will NOT be given?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carboprost.

 

  • Carboprost (or Prostadin) is a15-methyl analogues of PGF2α
  • It is Contraindicated in asthmatic women as it causes bronchoconstriction
  • Other drugs that are given for atonic PPH 
  1. Oxytocin
  2. Methylergometrine
  3. Oxytocin + Ergometrine (Syntometrine)
  4. Misoprostol

 

 

Ref: Page no 363, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Pack the cervix and remove the pack after 4-6 hours
Suture the cervical tear vaginally
Laparotomy and suture the cervical tear from above
Administer anti-fibrinolytics

questions.text: A 24y woman delivers a 3.4kg baby by an outlet forceps (For prolonged 2nd stage) at 38 weeks. Following the delivery of the baby, the placenta is delivered completely. After a few minutes, profuse bleeding is observed. The uterus is well contracted. The vagina and cervix are examined and a cervical tear is noted. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suture the cervical tear vaginally.

  • This is traumatic PPH and the cause is a cervical tear
  • The tear has to be sutured by visualization from below (Vaginal route)
  • IT should preferably be done in the OT under anesthesia with good visualization
  • Only if the tear is extending upward causing a broad ligament hematoma, then should it be explored by laparotomy

 

 

Ref: Page no 377, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Apparent shortening of the umbilical cord
Sudden gush of blood
Suprapubic bulge seen
Placenta felt in the vagina

questions.text: A 25y primigravida delivers 2.5kg after induction of labor at 40 weeks. Following delivery of the baby, Inj. Oxytocin is given as part of active management of the 3rd stage of labor. The resident asks the intern to inform him of signs of placental separation whilst he sees another patient. Which is NOT a sign of placental separation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Apparent shortening of the umbilical cord

  • Signs of placental separation are
    • Sudden gush of blood
    • Apparent lengthening of the cord
    • Suprapubic bulge
    • Placenta felt in the vagina
  • Remember that once signs of separation are seen, placenta is delivered by controlled cord traction
  • Placenta is defined as retained placenta, if it does not deliver within 30 minutes

 

 

Ref: Page no 364, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma

choices.text: Manual separation of placenta
Intraumbilical oxytocin
IV methylergometrine
Wait and watch

questions.text: A 32-year G2P1 delivers a baby at 39 weeks. Following delivery of the baby, the placenta does not separate even after 20 minutes. There is no excessive bleeding. She has received 10 IU oxytocin as part of active management of the 3rd stage of labor. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wait and watch

  • As only 20 minutes have elapsed and the patient is not bleeding, the next best step would be to wait and watch
  • Nothing needs to be done till 30 minutes if the patient is stable and there is no bleeding.
  • After 30 minutes also, the placenta is termed as retained placenta and a gentle controlled cord traction should be attempted.
  • If the placenta is separated and retained (Trapped placenta): Controlled cord traction should bring the placenta out
  • If the placenta is unseparated and retained (uncomplicated); then Manual removal of placenta should be done

 

 

Ref: Page no 367, JB Sharma textbook of obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: Brandt Andrews method
Crede’s method
Ritgen maneuver
Schultz Maneuver

questions.text: Identify the following maneuver:
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Brandt Andrews method

  • The image shows Brandt Andrews technique or controlled cord traction.
  • This involves pulling on the cord with one hand and suprapubic traction in the opposite direction to avoid uterine inversion
  • This is done after signs of separation of placenta
  • Crede’s method is a method of placental expulsion done by applying fundal pressure but it is not done now
  • Ritgen’s maneuver is controlled delivery of the head
  • Schulz and Duncan method are ways of placental separation (Remember as Shiny Schulz where the fetal side comes out 1st by central separation and Dirty Duncan where the maternal surface is seen 1st as lateral separation takes place first)

choices.text: Type B Lynch suture used.
Mifepristone used
More common in multipara
Associated with polyhydramnios.

questions.text: All are true regarding PPH except?
questions.solution:
Ans. ‘B’ Mifepristone used

  • PPH is more common in multipara due to laxed abdomen and associated factors like adherent placenta and anemia
  • Overdistension of uterus as in multiple pregnancy, hydramnios and large baby also lead to PPH
  • Incidence of atonic and traumatic PPH can be reduced with new advances or rather by intelligent anticipation, skilled supervision, prompt detection and effective institution of therapy.
  • B Lynch suture are used for management of PPH
  • Mifepristone is not used in the management of PPH.

 

 

 Ref: page no 1905, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 0.7–0.9
0.5-0.7
0.9-1.1
0.1–0.5

questions.text: A female presents with significant blood loss due to postpartum hemorrhage. What would be the shock index?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  0.9 to 1.1

 

  • Shock index = heart rate/systolic BP
  • Normal = 0.5–0.7
  • If it becomes 0.9–1.1 it indicates massive blood loss and need for intensive resuscitation.

 

Ref: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32769817/#:~:text=Abstract,detecting%20 postpartum%20 hemorrhage%20(PPH).

choices.text: Misoprostol
Oxytocin
Mifepristone
Carboprost

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for prevention and treatment of PPH except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mifepristone

 Commonly used Oxytocin in the management of PPH are:

  • Oxytocin/Carbetocin
  • Methylergometrine
  • Syntometrine – oxytocin + methylergonovine
  • 15 methyl PGF2α (carboprost)
  • Misoprostol (PGE1)

Oxytocin:

  • It stimulates the upper segment of the myometrium to contract rhythmically, which constricts spiral arteries and decreases blood flow through the uterus.
  • Clinical response is rapid and occurs within 3 to 5 minutes.
  • Side effects are very rare, but occasionally cause nausea and vomiting.
  • The only serious side effect ¡s dilutional hyponatremia which may happen with prolonged use.
  • Rapid IV infusion is associated with hypotension and tachycardia.
  • Oxytocin is dosed at 10 to 40 U/L (given as an IV infusion) for Atonic PPH.

Carboprost:

  • It is synthetic prostaglandin analogue of PGF2α.
  • Enhances uterine contractility and causes vasoconstriction.
  • IM dosing, initial: 250 mcg; if needed, may repeat at 15- to 90-minute intervals; maximum total dose 2 mg (8 doses).
  • In 75% of cases, a successful clinical response is reached within 30 min.
  • The reported side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bronchospasm, and hypertension
  • The recommendation is that the drug be given with caution to patients with hepatic or cardiovascular disease, asthma, or hypersensitivity to the drug. -
  • Clinical response may be enhanced with concomitant use of oxytocin.

Methylergometrine:

  • It is a semisynthetic ergot alkaloid.
  • It causes generalized smooth-muscle contraction in which the upper and lower segments of the uterus contract tetanically.
  • It ¡s available as 0.2 mg/mI ampoule for iv/im use.
  • Side effects are very rare, but occasionally cause nausea and vomiting.
  • This drug is contraindicated in
    • HTN in pregnancy
    • Heart disease in pregnancy
    • Severe anemia
    • After delivery of 1st twin in twin delivery
    • Rh incompatible couples
  • Onset of action (tablet) is within 5 to 10 minutes.
  • Used 0.2 mg 3 to 4 times /day in the puerperium for 2 to 7 days.
  • Onset of the IM dose is 2 to 5 minutes.

Misoprostol:

  • Synthetic prostaglandin El analogue.
  • Initially developed for oral use
  • Other routes of administration Sublingual, Rectal, vaginal and Buccal.

choices.text: Activated drotrecogin alfa.
Hydrocortisone
Thyroxine (T4)
Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman who is otherwise healthy, has an uneventful vaginal delivery of a full-term infant. One day postpartum, she complains of visual changes and a severe headache. Two hours after this, she is found unresponsive and profoundly hypotensive. She is intubated and put on mechanical ventilation. Her BP is 68/28 mmHg. Heart rate is 140 bp. O2 saturation is 95% on FiO2 of 0.40. Physical exam is unremarkable. Lab tests are notable for glucose of 48 mg/ dl with a normal hematocrit and TLC. Which of the following will reverse her hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydrocortisone

 

  • This patient has evidence of Sheehan syndrome after giving birth.
  • In this syndrome, the postpartum hypoplastic pituitary is at increased risk for hemorrhage and/or infarction. This leads to bilateral visual changes, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • In severe cases, cardiovascular collapse and altered levels of consciousness may be observed.
  • Laboratory evaluation commonly shows hypoglycemia.
  • Pituitary computed tomography (CT) or MRI may show signs of sellar hemorrhage if present. Involvement of all pituitary hormones may be seen, although the most acute findings are often hypoglycemia and hypotension from failure of ACTH.
  • The hypoglycemia and hypotension present in this patient suggest failure of the glucocorticoid system; thus, treatment with a corticosteroid is indicated. There is no evidence of sepsis; thus, antibiotics and drotrecogin alfa are not indicated. With a normal hematocrit and no reported evidence of massive hemorrhage, packed red cell transfusion is unlikely to be helpful. Although TSH production is undoubtedly low in this patient, the most immediate concern is replacement of glucocorticoid

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3183525/

choices.text: 1,2,3
1,2,3,4
1,3,4
1,3

questions.text:
Which amongst the following are uterotonic drugs used for PPH?

  1. Oxytocin
  2. Misoprostol
  3. PGF2a
  4. Dinoprostone
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1,2,3

Uterotonic drugs are those that cause vigorous contraction of the uterus and are used for treatment of atonic PPH

  1. Oxytocin
  2. Carbetocin
  3. Misoprostol (PGE1)
  4. Methylergometrine
  5. Carboprost (!5 methyl analogue of PGF2α)

Medical Management of PPH

 

 

Ref: Page no 1905, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 1350
1500
550
1000

questions.text: Blood loss more than _____ ml following LSCS is PPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  1000

Postpartum Hemorrhage

  • The traditional definition of primary PPH: Hemorrhage is blood loses over 500 ml or more from the genital tract within 24 hours of the vaginal birth of a baby or 1000 ml or more after a cesarean delivery
  • PPH can be minor (500 -1000 ml) or major (more than 1000 ml)
  • The four important causes of PPH are 4 T’s
    • Tone (Atonic uterus)
    • Trauma
    • Tissue (retained)
    • Thrombin (Coagulopathy)
  • Massive obstetric hemorrhage is variably defined as blood loss from uterus or genital tract > 1500 ml or a decrease in hemoglobin of >4 gm/dl or acute loss requiring transfusion of > 4 units of packed cell transfusion.

 

 

Ref: Page 1893, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: ​​​Early cord clamping
Uterine massage
Modified Brandt Andrews technique
Uterotonic agents

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of AMTSL?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

  • Described by the WHO in 2007
  • Involves mainly 3 basic steps.
    • Administering a uterotonic
    • Controlled cord traction
    • Uterine massage
  • AMTSL prevents atonic PPH.
  • In 2012, the WHO issued new guidelines for AMTSL which essentially emphasized the main 3 things but with additional information which was
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Do Controlled cord traction only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
    • Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who’ve received uterotonic; instead; postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.
    • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care (This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed)
  • In 2018, the WHO issued further guidelines on which other uterotonics can be used for AMTSL. These include:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (!00 mcg IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 OR 600 mcg PO – to be used where Skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV EXCEPT in hypertensive women))
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
  • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH

 

 

Ref: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/277276/9789241550420-eng.pdf

choices.text: Pituitary adenoma
Premature ovarian failure
Sheehan syndrome
Simmonds syndrome

questions.text: A female sustained massive PPH during delivery and presented with failure of lactation and amenorrhea 1 year later. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sheehan syndrome

 

Sheehan syndrome:

 

  • Sheehan syndrome (ie, postpartum hypopituitarism) is a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.
  • The pituitary gland is enlarged in pregnancy and prone to infarction from hypovolemic shock.
  • Damage to the pituitary can be mild or severe, and can affect the secretion of one, several, or all of its hormones.
  • A common presentation is a combination of failure to lactate post delivery and amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea, but any of the manifestations of hypopituitarism (eg, hypotension, hyponatremia, hypothyroidism) can occur any time from the immediate postpartum period to years after delivery.
  • If the patient remains hypotensive after control of hemorrhage and volume replacement, she should be evaluated and treated for adrenal insufficiency immediately
  • Evaluation of other hormonal deficiencies can be deferred until four to six weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 565, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

choices.text: TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required.
TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.
TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required
TXA should be administered at a dose of 0.5 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 15 minutes if required

questions.text: In 2017, the WHO recommended the use of tranexamic acid (TXA) for the treatment of PPH. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TXA should be administered at a dose of 1 g in 10 mL IV given as soon as PPH is identified and within 3 hours of birth. A second dose may be repeated after 30 minutes if required.

 

  • The World Health Organization recommends early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth in addition to standard care for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum hemorrhage following vaginal birth or cesarean section.
  • Administration of TXA should be considered as part of the standard PPH treatment package and be administered as soon as possible after onset of bleeding and within 3 hours of birth.
  • TXA for PPH treatment should not be initiated more than 3 hours after birth
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of whether the bleeding is due to genital tract trauma or other causes.
  • TXA should be administered at a fixed dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) IV at 1 mL per minute (i.e., administered over 10 minutes), with a second dose of 1 g IV if bleeding continues after 30 minutes.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for treatment of PPH. Research on other routes of TXA administration is a priority.

 

REF: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/259379/WHO-RHR-17.21-eng.pdf

choices.text: Internal iliac artery
Utero-ovarian anastomosis
Uterine artery
Ovarian artery

questions.text: A 28y primi undergoes a cesarean section for fetal distress. Following delivery of the fetus, the lower segment is sutured but the uterus is atonic and starts bleeding. Despite all medical management, the uterus remains atonic. A decision for stepwise devascularization is taken. Which is the first vessel to be ligated?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Uterine artery

Stepwise Devascularization is a surgical procedure to reduce blood loss in PPH. The following vessels are ligated in this order

  1. Uterine artery (u/l or b/l)
  2. Utero-ovarian anastomoses (u/l or b/l)
  3. B/l internal iliac artery ligation (Ant division)
  1. Uterine artery ligation
    • 90% of blood to the uterus is from uterine A
    • Done at the level of utero-vesical fold of peritoneum
  2. Utero-ovarian anastomosis:

Utero-ovarian anastomosis is typically performed laparoscopically, which is a minimally invasive surgical technique that involves making small incisions in the abdomen. This approach can result in less pain and faster recovery compared to traditional open surgery.

  1. Internal Iliac Artery
    • Done in atonic/ traumatic PPH; broad ligament hematoma.
    • IF bilateral ligation is done, the pulse pressure is reduced by 80%; mean arterial pressure by 25% and blood flow by 50%
    • Ligation is done 3-4 cm distal to the bifurcation of the origin of the internal iliac (so that the post division is not inadvertently ligated)
    • Always check the femoral pulsations post ligation (inadvertent ligation of the external iliac artery may sometimes happen)

 

 

Ref: Page no 2025, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Cho’s suture
B Lynch suture
Hayman suture
Isthmic cervical apposition

questions.text: While assisting a cesarean section for placenta previa, the patient starts bleeding. The gynecologist applies the following suture on the uterus and asks the name of it. What is this suture called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B Lynch suture

 

  • Compression sutures are used in surgical management of PPH, usually as a 1st line option in atonic PPH
  • The following sutures have been described

 

1. B Lynch (vertical Brace): These are preferred in women who have undergone a cesarean section and the lower segment uterine incision is already there

 

 

2. Hayman suture: 2 separate sutures (brace like) without opening the cavity of the uterus

 

 

3. Cho’s sutures: multiple square sutures

 

 

4. Isthmic cervical apposition: Compression sutures in the lower uterine segment

 

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Reposit the uterus and start Oxytocin.
Immediately arrange blood and start 20U IV oxytocin.
Immediate ultrasound
Laparotomy

questions.text: A 25y G4P3 presents at 37 weeks in labor. She quickly progresses and delivers soon after. Immediately after delivery of the baby, the placenta expels. The patient suddenly complains of abdominal pain and collapses. On examination, the uterus is not palpable on abdominal examination and on vaginal examination, a mass is felt. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Reposit the uterus and start Oxytocin.

  • This is uterine inversion.
  • Acute uterine inversion is seen after delivery and is a rare occurrence.
  • IT can be incomplete or complete.

Etiology

  • Adherent placenta
  • Fundally implanted placenta.
  • Short cord
  • Traction on the cord before separation of placenta
  • Crede’s expression while the uterus is relaxed.

C/F

  • Pain abdomen
  • Hemorrhage
  • Shock without hemorrhage (neurogenic shock) due to pulling of ligaments
  • Postpartum collapse
  • On examination
  • Hypotension
  • Tachycardia
  • P/A: uterine fundus not palpable (Depending on degree of inversion)
  • L/E or P/V: fleshy mass seen outside the introitus (this is the inverted uterus – seen in complete inversion) OR on P/V, fleshy mass felt

Treatment

  • Call for help
  • Secure IV access
  • Blood – if bleeding
  • If the inversion happens in the presence of the doctor/ person conducting delivery: immediate reposition is the rule. The sooner this is done, the better as after some time, edema will set in and it will be difficult. The part which inverts first (fundus) has to be reposed last. After repositioning, keep the hand in for sometime and start oxytocin and remove the hand gently once the uterus starts contracting. This is called Johnson Maneuver.
  • O’Sullivan hydrostatic method: The operator occludes the introitus with his or her hands and a large volume of warm saline is infused with a douche nozzle to distend the vagina which pushes the fundus back to position.
  • Other vaginal approaches
    • Spinelli’s method: cutting the cervical ring anteriorly and repositioning the uterus
    • Kustner method: cutting the cervical ring posteriorly and repositioning the uterus
  • Abdominal approach
    • Huntington method: Allis forceps is used to take out the dimpled fundus
    • Haultain method: the cervical ring cut posteriorly on laparotomy and inversion corrected by pulling out the dimpled fundus

 

 

Ref: Page no 370, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Postpartum hemorrhage
Disseminated Intravascular coagulation.
Amniotic Fluid Embolism
Uterine inversion

questions.text: A 30y G2P1 delivers a 3kg baby. 5 minutes after delivery of the placenta, she suddenly collapses. Her pulse and BP are unrecordable. This is followed by profuse vaginal bleeding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Amniotic Fluid Embolism

  • Triad of
    • Hemodynamic instability
    • Cardiorespiratory collapse
    • DIC
    • Is seen in Amniotic Fluid Embolism
  • AFE is a rare condition with high maternal mortality
  • Criteria to diagnose AFE is

  • In AFE, initially there is Postpartum collapse followed by Bleeding (due to DIC) whereas in PPH there is bleeding followed by collapse

 

 

Ref: Page no 1932, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Carry out uterine massage.
Insert two 14G cannula and start I/V fluids
Give oxytocin infusion
Palpate the uterus to determine its consistency

questions.text: A P3L3 woman who had normal vaginal delivery develops PPH. The third stage was managed actively, and placenta and membranes were expelled completely. What is the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. ‘B’ Insert two 14G cannula and start IV fluids

This patient has developed PPH but always the first step in management - when any patient comes with bleeding is - general resuscitation which includes inserting two 14G cannula and starting I/V fluids.

 

 

Ref: page no 1905, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 50 microgram IV
100 microgram IM
150 microgram IV
200 microgram IV

questions.text: Dose of Carbetocin used for PPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 100 microgram IM

  • Carbetocin (long-acting Oxytocin) 100 microgram IM/ IV is very useful to prevent postpartum hemorrhage.
  • It is a heat stable, long acting, synthetic analogue of oxytocin
  • Useful where cold chain for oxytocin cannot be maintained
  • Approved by the WHO (2018) for prevention of atonic PPH (component of AMTSL)

 

 

ReF: https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/277276/9789241550420-eng.pdf

choices.text: a,b,c are correct
a and c are correct
a, b and d are correct
a,b,c,d are correct

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding management of PPH:

  1. Uterine massage is the first step in management.
  2. Oxytocin is given to all patients.
  3. Suction and evacuation is done
  4. B lynch suture is put if medical management fails
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a, b and d are correct

Postpartum Hemorrhage

Causes, Predisposing Factors, and Vulnerable Patients

 

 

 

Ref: Page no 1904, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Pulmonary embolism; perform a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)
Atelectasis; perform a chest X-ray
Pneumonia; obtain a sputum culture
Peripartum cardiomyopathy; perform an echocardiogram

questions.text: An hour after giving birth, a 30-year-old woman complains of severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia. She had a vaginal delivery with an episiotomy. What is the most likely complication, and what diagnostic test is indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pulmonary embolism; perform a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)

 

Explanation:

 

  • The symptoms of severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and tachycardia in a postpartum woman can be alarming and suggest a cardiovascular or pulmonary origin. Given the symptomatology of severe chest pain and shortness of breath along with tachycardia, pulmonary embolism (PE) is a leading concern. Pregnancy and the postpartum period increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), making PE a more likely complication in this context. A CTPA is the most appropriate and definitive test for diagnosing a PE as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries to detect any emboli.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Atelectasis involves collapse of part of the lung and is common after anesthesia or due to immobility. It usually presents with mild to moderate dyspnea and occasionally tachypnea.  Atelectasis is typically not associated with severe chest pain. A chest X-ray is the standard imaging modality for identifying atelectasis but given the severity of the symptoms, atelectasis is less likely to be the primary issue here.
  • Option C: Postpartum pneumonia could present with shortness of breath, chest pain, fever, and a productive cough. A sputum culture can be helpful in identifying the causative organism if pneumonia is suspected. However, pneumonia is generally less likely to present so acutely with severe chest pain and without other respiratory infection symptoms like fever and cough.
  • Option D: Peripartum cardiomyopathy is a form of heart failure that can occur during the last month of pregnancy or the months following delivery. It can present with shortness of breath, fatigue, and signs of heart failure. An echocardiogram is used to diagnose this condition by assessing the heart's function and structure. While peripartum cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, the sudden onset of severe chest pain is less characteristic of this condition.

 

In this scenario, the most likely complication based on the acute presentation and symptoms is a pulmonary embolism. Hence, the indicated diagnostic test is a CTPA, which would provide rapid and clear evidence for or against the presence of a PE, which is essential given the potential for rapid deterioration and the need for prompt treatment in such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnancy and the postpartum period increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), making PE a more likely complication in this context. A CTPA is the most appropriate and definitive test for diagnosing a PE as it allows direct visualization of the pulmonary arteries to detect any emboli.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 1016

choices.text: Normal third stage of labor; continue to monitor
Uterine atony; administer uterotonic medications and perform uterine massage
Retained placenta; proceed to manual removal
Cervical laceration; suture the laceration

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has just delivered a healthy baby. After the baby’s birth, she experiences heavy bleeding, and her uterus is not contracting adequately. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uterine atony; administer uterotonic medications and perform uterine massage

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine atony, the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, occurs when the uterus fails to contract adequately after the baby’s delivery. The initial management involves administering uterotonic medications (e.g., oxytocin) and performing uterine massage to stimulate uterine contractions.

 

Other options:

 

  • Retained placenta and cervical laceration (traumatic PPH)  are other causes of PPH but are not associated with atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of PPH: Remember 4 Ts

 

  • Tone: Atonic uterus: Most common causes of PPH
  • Trauma: Traumatic PPH
  • Tissue: Retained placenta
  • Thrombin: Coagulation disorder

 

Ref: Page no 1904, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Postpartum hemorrhage; administer blood transfusion
Amniotic fluid embolism; provide supportive care
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC); initiate anticoagulation therapy
Uterine rupture; prepare for surgical repair

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman experiences a sudden drop in blood pressure, tachycardia, and confusion after delivering her baby. On examination, her uterus is well contracted with no active bleeding. She has no significant medical or surgical history. What is the most likely complication, and what is the initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Amniotic fluid embolism; provide supportive care

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical presentation of a sudden drop in blood pressure, tachycardia, and confusion after delivery with a firm uterus and no active bleeding is suggestive of a non-hemorrhagic shock, which does not fit with the typical signs of postpartum hemorrhage or uterine rupture.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but serious and potentially fatal condition that can occur during labor or after delivery. It's characterized by a sudden onset of hypotension, respiratory distress, and coagulopathy, often accompanied by neurological symptoms such as confusion or seizures due to an embolic event. The diagnosis is clinical and one of exclusion. There's no specific treatment, so supportive care is critical. This includes maintaining oxygenation and hemodynamic support, as well as addressing any coagulopathy that may arise.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is characterized by heavy bleeding of more than 500 mL after vaginal delivery or 1000 mL after cesarean delivery. The clinical signs would typically include a drop in blood pressure and an increase in heart rate. However, the uterus may often be atonic, although it can be firm in cases of retained placental fragments or genital tract tears. Initial treatment would focus on identifying the source of bleeding and managing it with uterotonics, repair of any lacerations, and blood transfusions if necessary.
  • Option C: DIC is a secondary condition that can occur as a complication of several obstetric emergencies, such as severe PPH, sepsis, or AFE. It's characterized by activation of clotting in the small blood vessels throughout the body, which can lead to a paradoxical increase in bleeding due to the consumption of clotting factors and platelets. Treatment is primarily focused on treating the underlying cause and supporting the coagulation system with blood products as necessary.
  • Option D: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the wall of the uterus and is typically accompanied by severe abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and sometimes vaginal bleeding. The uterus would not be described as firm in such a case. If the rupture is complete, there would often be signs of fetal distress or even maternal hemodynamic instability if there is significant intra-abdominal bleeding. Surgical repair is necessary for uterine rupture, and it's an obstetric emergency that requires immediate intervention.

 

Given the clinical presentation the most likely diagnosis is amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amniotic Fluid Embolism should be suspected in a patient who has cardio-respiratory collapse immediately following delivery or anytime in labor.

 

Criteria for diagnosing Amniotic Fluid Embolism

 

Clinical onset during labor or within 30 minutes of placenta delivery

 

Abrupt onset of cardiorespiratory arrest, or both hypotension and respiratory compromise

 

Overt disseminated intravascular coagulopathy.

 

No fever > 30°C

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 785

choices.text: Uterine inversion; manually reposition the uterus
Uterine atony; administer uterotonic medications
Retained placenta; perform manual removal
Uterine rupture; prepare for emergency surgery

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has delivered her baby, and the placenta is delivered intact. Shortly after, she reports severe lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a feeling of "something coming out." What is the likely complication, and what is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Uterine inversion; manually reposition the uterus

 

Explanation: Uterine inversion is a rare but serious complication where the uterus turns inside out, usually immediately following delivery. The description of severe pain, bleeding, and the sensation of something coming out is classic for uterine inversion. It must be promptly treated due to the potential for significant hemorrhage and shock. The initial step in management would be an attempt to manually reposition the uterus to its normal position, often followed by administration of uterotonics once the uterus is repositioned to help maintain uterine tone and prevent re-inversion.

 

Management of acute uterine inversion:

 

  • Call for help.
  • Resuscitation and reposition go hand in hand if inversion occurs in labour room.
  • It is best reposited in the labour room itself and immediately after giving analgesics.
  • The part of uterus which comes out last goes in first.
  • Keep your first inside the uterus till the oxytocic is given and the uterus contracts.
  • Keep the patient on oxytocics for 24 hours post reposition.
  • Avoid pressing on the fundus post reposition to prevent recurrence.

 

Other options:

 

  • Uterine atony, a condition where the uterus fails to contract after delivery, is the most common cause of pph. It typically presents with bleeding and a soft, boggy uterus on palpation.
  • If the placenta or fragments of it are retained inside the uterus, this can also cause PPH since the uterine muscles cannot contract effectively. However, the scenario described indicates that the placenta was delivered intact, ruling out retained placental tissue as the cause of the symptoms.
  • Uterine rupture involves a tear in the muscular wall of the uterus, which is an obstetric emergency. It can result in severe abdominal pain and bleeding, and the fetus may be expelled into the abdominal cavity. However, uterine rupture is unlikely in this case as the placenta has been delivered intact, and there's no mention of fetal distress or loss of fetal station, which would be indicative of such a rupture.

 

Given the symptoms described and the fact that the placenta was already delivered, the most likely complication is uterine inversion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of acute uterine inversion:

 

  • Call for help.
  • Resuscitation and reposition go hand in hand if inversion occurs in labour room.
  • It is best reposited in the labour room itself and immediately after giving analgesics.
  • The part of uterus which comes out last goes in first.
  • Keep your first inside the uterus till the oxytocic is given and the uterus contracts.
  • Keep the patient on oxytocics for 24 hours post reposition.
  • Avoid pressing on the fundus post reposition to prevent recurrence.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 761

https://fogsi.org/wp-content/uploads/fogsi-focus/FOGSI-Focus-Life-Saving-Emergency-Obstetric-Surgeries-2023.pdf

choices.text: Vaginal hematoma; surgical drainage
Urethral injury; urethral catheterization
Uterine atony; administer uterotonic medications
Rectovaginal fistula; surgical repair

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivers her first baby vaginally. She begins to complain of severe rectal pain and inability to pass urine. On examination, the perineum is swollen and ecchymotic. What is the likely complication, and what is the initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vaginal hematoma; surgical drainage

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation of severe rectal pain, inability to pass urine, perineal swelling, and ecchymosis is consistent with a vaginal hematoma. The initial treatment is surgical drainage to relieve the hematoma and prevent complications.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Urethral injury is less common and might not directly lead to swelling and ecchymosis of the perineum. However, an injury to the urethra might cause difficulty with urination. Management of a suspected urethral injury typically includes urethral catheterization to ensure bladder drainage and to help define the injury.
  • Option C: Uterine atony is a condition where the uterus fails to contract after delivery, leading to postpartum hemorrhage. The primary symptoms would be bleeding and a soft, boggy uterus on palpation, rather than rectal pain and difficulty with urination.
  • Option D: A rectovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the rectum and vagina that can occur as a complication of childbirth, especially after a traumatic delivery. While a rectovaginal fistula could cause fecal matter to pass through the vagina, it would not typically present with acute urinary retention or severe rectal pain immediately postpartum. The management involves surgical repair, but this is not done immediately postpartum and would not be the first-line treatment for the symptoms described.

 

Based on the given symptoms - severe rectal pain, inability to pass urine, and a swollen, bruised perineum - the most likely complication in this scenario is a vaginal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of severe rectal pain, inability to pass urine, perineal swelling, and vulval swelling and ecchymosis soon after delivery is consistent with a vaginal hematoma. The initial treatment is surgical drainage to relieve the hematoma and prevent complications.

 

 

Ref : Williams Textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 764
